reading_mnemonic: 巣 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.
巣 is a standalone word here, so it uses the same reading that you learned when you learned the vocabulary.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know the word 主催 already as well.

You should have learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic to help you, just in case:

What are you trying <vocabulary>to resemble</vocabulary>?? Is that... oh no. A <reading>knee</reading> (に) face resemble surgery, where you make your face look like your knee and vice versa? Do you know how dangerous that surgery is?
The reading is the same as the other storehouse reading you learned earlier with 庫. They're basically the same thing, and lucky for you they share the same reading too (<reading>くら</reading>).
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 催促 first.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

For the reading, just think about this feeling you're having (this lamenting grieving one). Then, decide you're done with it. <reading>投げ</reading>る (throw) it out the window. You don't want these feels anymore!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

When you finally have a <vocabulary>grave</vocabulary> and you're dead and buried, your one wish is for the New Zealand All Blacks to do the <reading>Haka</reading> (はか) over your grave. If you don't know what the haka is, look it up, it's pretty neat.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 壊す, so try not to break any of your memories and remember this.
The reading is 壊れる and 物 put together.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You are the <vocabulary>grandchild</vocabulary> of your grandfather. His favorite thing is to call you a <reading>maggo</reading>t (まご). Your grandfather was in the military and is very hard on you, maggot.
For the reading, think about the person you know with the most <vocabulary>wealth</vocabulary>. It is <reading>Tommy</reading> (とみ) Hilfiger.

Think about the richest person you know. That person is <reading>Tom</reading> (とむ). Imagine Tom as being super rich. If you don't know a Tom, think of a famous Tom, like Tom Cruise, who definitely is pretty rich.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
I'd like <vocabulary>to inquire</vocabulary> about a few things. Wait, what? You won't cooperate? How about I just <reading>taze</reading> (たず) you with this tazer then? BzzzbbzbhhhAHHHHHH!
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.
The readings are from the words 巣 and 立つ put together. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes たつ to だつ!

The reading is obi (おび), so if you know the meaning, you know the reading as well! If you need an extra reminder, ask yourself "What is the first letter in belt?" Hmm, I can't remember. <reading>OH! "B"</reading> (おび)! I remember now.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
The reading comes from what you learned in the kanji, nice job.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

The 学 is read correctly, in terms of what you learned. The 幾 and 何 is weird, though. Just think how when you're asking a question in Japanese, you end the sentence with か. So, it's like, "何か????" and that's why it becomes <reading>か</reading>. Then, for 幾 think about how the <reading>key</reading> (き) to answering geometry questions correctly is figuring out "how many" sides something has. So, "do you have the <reading>key</reading>か?"
The reading is a combination of kun'yomi and on'yomi readings. That being said, both readings for both kanji are the readings you learned with the kanji so you should be able to read this.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading.

Lucky for you, the kanji readings for transitive and intransitive verbs are almost always the same. Once you learn one, you know them both! This reading is the same as 延ばす.
The readings are the ones you learned with the individual kanji. Put them together and you'll know this is <vocabulary>Tokushima Prefecture</vocabulary>.

The readings are 徳 and the vocab 川 put together into one word. Once you can read this, you'll know the meaning too, so focus on the reading for this one. Just watch out for the rendaku that changes かわ to がわ!
The reading is 思い and 詰める put together into one reading.
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!
The reading is shared with 恐ろしい, which is "scary." Use that, and don't be afraid. You'll be able to learn this reading yet.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You learned this reading for 我 when you learned 我が. Just watch out for 国, which you might expect to rendaku here, but doesn't!

Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: While you <vocabulary>sweep</vocabulary> you laugh. "<reading>HA</reading> (は) HA HA!" Just imagine yourself doing this, or do it for real if you want to clean up a bit.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. For this one though, you have to remember to read the 除 part as じ. Just keep in mind that <kanji>cleaning</kanji> (cleanliness) is next to godliness and so is <reading>Je</reading>sus (じ). So, Jesus is like cleaning. Easy.

You are looking for a <reading>sagger</reading> (さが) amongst the products you're shipping off overseas. The saggers are the boxes that have weird lumps sagging out of them, which means they broke and are getting things wet. So, find the saggers. Go <vocabulary>to search for</vocabulary> them, because they could ruin the whole shipment.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The すく in the reading is a lot like the <reading>scue</reading> (すくう) part of <vocabulary>to rescue</vocabulary>, don't you think? Hopefully you do, so you can make the connection.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

Think about something scattering. That something is <reading>chee</reading>se (ち), scattering all over the floor, going everywhere, getting in everything. Ugh, you hate how cheese scatters, don't you?
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The ほ goes to ぽ, though.

The reading is different from what you learned with the kanji. But as I told you <vocabulary>already</vocabulary>, I'll be there on <reading>Su-day</reading> (すで). It's like Sunday, but not quite the same. Imagine your confusion when someone says this over and over, but you don't know what Suday is.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, but here's a mnemonic in case you need a refresher:

You may know of Dora the Explorer. But have you heard about her dirty, <vocabulary>mud</vocabulary>dy brother, <reading>Doro</reading> (<ja>どろ</ja>)? They're like a team. And because of all the exploring he does, Doro is always covered in mud.

This is a jukugo word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

There's another way to read this word that uses both on'yomi readings (でいすい). It's mostly used in more formal or technical situations though, so we're focusing on the どろみず reading here!
Speaking of things that illuminate, your <reading>hand</reading>s (手) illuminate all the time for some reason.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading comes from 積もる, so pile up your knowledge and remember it that way.

Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:

Just imagine there’s <vocabulary>powder</vocabulary> all over <reading>Cona</reading>n’s (こな) hands and face. Detective Conan, that is. Conan has been investigating some kind of bakery murder. He had to dig through sacks of flour to find the hidden murder weapon (rolling pin, naturally) and now Conan is just covered in the white, starchy powder.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading comes from 絶える.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

When you start <vocabulary>to knit</vocabulary>, you always end up with the same thing every time when you're done, no matter what you're trying to make: The letter "<reading>A</reading>" (あ). It's so frustrating that you can't knit anything else.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

The reading is all on'yomi readings, which you learned for all but 花. Instead, 花 is か, and to remember that you can think about how the only way to escape the <vocabulary>hay fever</vocabulary> is to jump in your <reading>ca</reading>r and turn on the filter. Sweet, sweet relief.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
For the reading, think about something that's <vocabulary>showy</vocabulary>... in particular, <reading>花</reading>s (はな). Flowers are super showy, always showing off their colors and stuff.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

The reading is 見 and 詰める.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi of both kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
The reading is the 物 reading that's もつ. You can know this because you have to carry the freight and cargo (持つ it!).
The reading comes from 迷う, so use that so you aren't lead astray too.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
You would like to exclude your <reading>nose</reading> (のぞ) because you don't like your nose. Imagine your strong feelings about your nose as you decide to exclude it.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.
This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.
<vocabulary>Male</vocabulary> animals can be kind of pushy, always trying <reading>to push</reading> (押す) other animals around, trying to be the alpha and all.

The readings are the kun'yomi readings, which is probably A-Okay for 犬, but for 雄 you'll want to think about how a male dog is probably pretty pushy, always trying <reading>to push</reading> (押す) other dogs around, being male and moody and all that.

For the reading, think about what is separating. It's quite sad, because all of the <reading>花</reading>s (はな) are separating from their stems and falling on the ground, and nobody knows why. Just falling off and being sad.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

What are you so surprised by? Your friend's <reading>odor</reading> (おどろ). Think of a friend that you wouldn't expect to be so smelly. Then, be surprised by the odor. Eww, bro, you have to take a shower.
This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

This word uses the kun'yomi readings. Since you didn't learn that reading for 粉 with the kanji, here's a mnemonic to help you out. What sort of people like <vocabulary>wheat flour</vocabulary> the most? <reading>子</reading>! 子 like wheat flour the most since it is both fun to eat and to play with. Silly 子, wheat flour is a food, not a toy.
The reading is 鼻 and 詰まる put together. the 詰まり is rendaku'd, probably because you're trying to say this word with a stuffy nose.
